policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing baseline configuration management practices including development, documentation, review, and maintenance of system baselines
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.01 requires 'develop and maintain under configuration control' which necessitates formal policy guidance for configuration management activities

procedures.name: Baseline Configuration Development Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for creating initial baseline configurations including documentation of connectivity, operations, communications, network topology, and system component placement
procedures.rationale: Control requires 'develop and maintain...baseline configuration' - procedure defines HOW to create and document baselines per NIST discussion requirements

procedures.name: Baseline Configuration Review and Update Procedure
procedures.description: Process for periodic review and updating of baseline configurations including triggers for updates (component installations/modifications) and formal review/approval workflow
procedures.rationale: Control part (b) requires 'review and update the baseline configuration' at organization-defined frequency and when changes occur

procedures.name: Configuration Control Procedure
procedures.description: Process for maintaining baseline configurations under version control including change tracking, approval requirements, and documentation standards
procedures.rationale: Control requires baselines to be 'under configuration control' which necessitates formal version control and change tracking procedures

executionEvidence.name: Current Baseline Configuration Documents
executionEvidence.description: Documented baseline configurations showing: system components list, network topology diagrams, connectivity specifications, operational procedures, security settings, placement in system architecture, version number, date created, approval signatures
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST requires 'current baseline configuration' - must be available and reflect actual system state. 90-day threshold aligns with typical quarterly review cycles for configuration management

executionEvidence.name: Baseline Configuration Review Records
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly review records showing: baseline reviewed, changes identified, updates approved, review date, reviewer names/signatures, next review date scheduled
executionEvidence.rationale: Control requires periodic review at 'organization-defined frequency' - quarterly is CIS Benchmark recommendation. 120-day threshold allows one missed cycle before concern

executionEvidence.name: Configuration Change Records
executionEvidence.description: Records of baseline updates triggered by system changes showing: component installed/modified, baseline update date, changes documented, approval obtained, new baseline version created
executionEvidence.rationale: Control part (b) requires updating baseline 'when system components are installed or modified' - demonstrates compliance with change-triggered updates

executionEvidence.name: Configuration Version Control Logs
executionEvidence.description: Version control system logs showing: baseline versions, modification dates, who made changes, approval workflow completion, configuration items tracked
executionEvidence.frequency: Continuous logging of all baseline changes
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates baseline is 'maintained under configuration control' - version control is essential evidence of configuration control implementation

operationalActivities: Develop initial baseline configuration for new systems or major system changes
Document baseline configuration including all required elements per NIST discussion
Place baseline configuration under version control system
Conduct quarterly reviews of baseline configurations
Update baseline configurations when components are installed or modified
Obtain formal approval for baseline configuration changes
Maintain baseline configurations to reflect current enterprise architecture
Create new baseline versions as system changes over time

policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing secure configuration settings establishment and deviation approval processes
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.02 requires 'establish, document, and implement configuration settings' which requires high-level policy guidance on secure configuration practices

policies.name: Secure Configuration Standards Policy
policies.description: Policy adopting organization-wide secure configuration standards (e.g., CIS Benchmarks, DISA STIGs) as baseline for restrictive configuration settings
policies.rationale: Control requires settings 'reflect the most restrictive mode' - policy must define what standards/benchmarks organization uses to determine restrictive settings

procedures.name: Configuration Settings Establishment Procedure
procedures.description: Process for identifying and documenting required configuration settings for each system component type including security parameters, registry settings, account/file/directory permissions, function/port/protocol settings per recognized standards
procedures.rationale: Control part (a) requires 'establish, document...configuration settings' - procedure defines HOW to identify organization-defined settings per NIST discussion

procedures.name: Secure Configuration Implementation Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for applying configuration settings to systems including testing, validation, and rollback procedures
procedures.rationale: Control requires 'implement...configuration settings' - operational procedure needed for consistent implementation across systems

procedures.name: Configuration Deviation Approval Procedure
procedures.description: Process for requesting, documenting, and approving deviations from established configuration settings including risk assessment, compensating controls, and time-limited approval
procedures.rationale: Control part (b) requires 'identify, document, and approve any deviations' - formal procedure ensures deviations are properly evaluated and authorized

executionEvidence.name: Documented Configuration Settings
executionEvidence.description: Configuration setting documents showing: system component types covered, specific settings required per type, security parameters defined, based on recognized standards (CIS/DISA STIGs), operational requirements considered, most restrictive mode justified
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST requires documented configuration settings per control text. Annual review is common practice; 18-month threshold allows reasonable staleness before major concern

executionEvidence.name: Configuration Implementation Evidence
executionEvidence.description: System scans or configuration audit reports showing: actual settings implemented, compliance with documented standards, systems covered, scan date, deviations identified
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates settings are 'implemented' as required. Monthly scanning aligns with CIS Implementation Group 1 recommendations. 45-day threshold allows one missed scan

executionEvidence.name: Configuration Deviation Approvals
executionEvidence.description: Deviation approval records showing: specific setting requiring deviation, system affected, business justification, risk assessment completed, compensating controls identified, approver signature, approval date, expiration date if time-limited
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: N/A - maintained for audit, but time-limited approvals should be reviewed for expiration
executionEvidence.rationale: Control part (b) explicitly requires 'identify, document, and approve' deviations - this is direct evidence of compliance

executionEvidence.name: Configuration Compliance Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports showing: percentage compliance with documented settings per system, deviations detected, unauthorized changes identified, remediation status, trend analysis over time
executionEvidence.rationale: Ongoing evidence that settings remain implemented and deviations are tracked. 60-day threshold allows two monthly cycles before concern

operationalActivities: Identify organization-defined configuration settings for each system component type
Document configuration settings based on common secure configuration checklists (CIS, DISA STIGs)
Implement configuration settings on all applicable systems
Conduct monthly automated configuration compliance scans
Review and approve deviation requests with risk assessment and compensating controls
Track and document all approved deviations from standard configurations
Review configuration settings annually and update as needed
Monitor configuration drift and remediate unauthorized changes

policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing configuration change control processes including change types requiring control, approval authorities, and security impact review requirements
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.03 requires systematic change control including 'review', 'approve or disapprove', and security consideration - requires policy-level governance

policies.name: Change Management Policy
policies.description: High-level policy defining change control framework, roles and responsibilities, emergency change procedures, and integration with incident response
policies.rationale: Control requires comprehensive change control including 'proposal, justification, implementation, testing, review, and disposition' per NIST discussion - policy establishes framework

procedures.name: Configuration Change Classification Procedure
procedures.description: Process for defining and identifying which system changes are configuration-controlled including criteria for standard vs. emergency changes, thresholds for change control requirement
procedures.rationale: Control part (a) requires 'define the types of changes...that are configuration-controlled' - procedure operationalizes this definition

procedures.name: Configuration Change Request and Review Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for submitting change requests, conducting security impact analysis, obtaining approvals, including required documentation, review criteria, approval workflow
procedures.rationale: Control part (b) requires 'review proposed...changes...and approve or disapprove...with explicit consideration for security impacts' - defines HOW reviews occur

procedures.name: Configuration Change Implementation Procedure
procedures.description: Process for implementing approved changes including testing requirements, implementation windows, documentation standards, rollback procedures, post-implementation validation
procedures.rationale: Control part (c) requires 'implement and document approved...changes' - procedure ensures consistent implementation and documentation

procedures.name: Configuration Change Monitoring Procedure
procedures.description: Process for ongoing monitoring of configuration-controlled changes including tracking mechanisms, review frequencies, metrics collection, issue escalation
procedures.rationale: Control part (d) requires 'monitor and review activities associated with configuration-controlled changes' - procedure defines monitoring activities

executionEvidence.name: Change Control Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Document defining: types of changes requiring configuration control, change categories (standard/emergency/urgent), thresholds for each category, approval authorities per category, security review requirements
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates compliance with part (a) 'define the types of changes' requirement. Annual review is best practice; 18-month threshold before significant staleness

executionEvidence.name: Change Request Records
executionEvidence.description: Individual change request tickets showing: change description, system affected, justification, security impact analysis completed, approval/disapproval decision, reviewer names, decision date, disposition rationale
executionEvidence.rationale: Direct evidence of part (b) 'review proposed...changes, and approve or disapprove' with security consideration. Each request is evidence of process execution

executionEvidence.name: Change Implementation Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: approved changes implemented, implementation date/time, implementer name, testing results, documentation updated, rollback procedures confirmed available, post-implementation validation completed
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates compliance with part (c) 'implement and document approved...changes' - shows changes were properly implemented per approval

executionEvidence.name: Change Monitoring Reports
executionEvidence.description: Monthly reports showing: configuration changes monitored, unauthorized changes detected, change success/failure rates, security impacts identified post-implementation, issues requiring remediation, metrics and trends
executionEvidence.rationale: Evidence of part (d) 'monitor and review activities associated with...changes' - demonstrates ongoing oversight. 60-day threshold allows two cycles before concern

executionEvidence.name: Change Advisory Board Meeting Minutes
executionEvidence.description: CAB meeting records showing: changes reviewed, security impact discussions, approval decisions made, attendees, meeting date, action items assigned
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates formal review process per part (b). Regular CAB meetings are industry best practice for change control governance

operationalActivities: Define and document types of system changes requiring configuration control
Submit change requests for all configuration-controlled changes
Conduct security impact analysis for each proposed change
Review and approve/disapprove change requests with explicit security consideration
Implement only approved configuration changes following documented procedures
Document all configuration change implementation details and results
Monitor configuration changes through automated tools and periodic reviews
Conduct regular Change Advisory Board meetings to review pending changes
Track and remediate unauthorized configuration changes
Review change control effectiveness and update procedures as needed

policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy requiring security impact analysis prior to system changes and post-implementation verification of security requirements
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.04 requires 'analyze changes to determine potential security impacts' and 'verify security requirements...continue to be satisfied' - requires policy mandate

procedures.name: Pre-Implementation Security Impact Analysis Procedure
procedures.description: Step-by-step process for conducting security impact analysis including reviewing security plans/policies, analyzing effects on security state, assessing supply chain impacts, identifying new risks, determining additional security requirements needed
procedures.rationale: Control part (a) requires 'analyze changes...to determine potential security impacts prior to change implementation' - procedure defines comprehensive analysis methodology per NIST discussion

procedures.name: Post-Implementation Security Verification Procedure
procedures.description: Process for verifying security requirements remain satisfied after changes including validation testing, compliance scanning, functionality verification, security control effectiveness testing
procedures.rationale: Control part (b) requires 'verify that security requirements...continue to be satisfied after...changes' - procedure ensures systematic verification

executionEvidence.name: Pre-Implementation Impact Analysis Reports
executionEvidence.description: Impact analysis documents for each significant change showing: system security plans reviewed, policies/procedures checked, potential effects on security state analyzed, supply chain partner impacts reviewed, new risks identified, risk assessment completed, additional security requirements determined, analyst signature, analysis date
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: N/A - must exist prior to each change implementation
executionEvidence.rationale: Direct evidence of part (a) requirement to 'analyze changes...prior to change implementation' - must demonstrate analysis occurred BEFORE implementation per control text

executionEvidence.name: Post-Implementation Verification Reports
executionEvidence.description: Verification reports showing: security requirements validated post-change, testing results documented, compliance scans completed, security controls tested, functionality verified, any security requirement failures identified and remediated, verifier signature, verification date
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: N/A - must exist within reasonable time after implementation
executionEvidence.rationale: Direct evidence of part (b) requirement to 'verify security requirements...continue to be satisfied after...changes' - demonstrates post-change validation occurred

executionEvidence.name: Risk Assessment Documentation for Changes
executionEvidence.description: Risk assessments conducted as part of impact analyses showing: change-introduced risks identified, likelihood and impact evaluated, risk mitigation strategies determined, residual risk assessed, risk acceptance decisions documented
executionEvidence.frequency: Per significant change requiring risk assessment
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: N/A - must align with change timeline
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion states 'impact analyses also include risk assessments' - demonstrates comprehensive impact analysis per requirement

executionEvidence.name: Security Requirements Traceability Matrix
executionEvidence.description: Living document showing: all security requirements for system, which changes affected each requirement, verification status post-change, any requirements no longer satisfied, remediation plans for failures
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates ongoing tracking of security requirements compliance as system changes occur. Essential for verifying part (b) compliance systematically

operationalActivities: Review system security plans before implementing changes
Analyze how proposed changes will affect system security state
Review impacts on supply chain partners when changes affect shared systems
Conduct risk assessments to identify new risks created by changes
Determine if additional security requirements are needed due to changes
Document all impact analysis findings prior to change approval
Conduct post-implementation verification testing for all security requirements
Validate that security controls remain effective after changes
Document verification results and remediate any security requirement failures
Maintain traceability between changes and affected security requirements

policies.name: Configuration Management Policy
policies.description: Organizational policy governing access restrictions for system changes including physical and logical access controls, qualification requirements for change personnel, and enforcement mechanisms
policies.rationale: NIST 03.04.05 requires 'define, document, approve, and enforce...access restrictions associated with changes' - requires high-level policy establishing access control framework for changes

procedures.name: Change Access Restrictions Definition Procedure
procedures.description: Process for defining which roles/individuals can access systems for change purposes including qualification criteria, training requirements, authorization levels per system/component type
procedures.rationale: Control requires 'define...access restrictions' - procedure establishes methodology for determining WHO can make changes based on qualifications per NIST discussion

procedures.name: Change Access Authorization Procedure
procedures.description: Process for granting, reviewing, and revoking change access including request workflow, approval requirements, periodic access reviews, qualification verification
procedures.rationale: Control requires 'approve...access restrictions' - procedure defines HOW access is authorized and managed for change activities

procedures.name: Change Access Enforcement Procedure
procedures.description: Process for enforcing access restrictions including physical access controls (facility access, locked rooms), logical access controls (privileged accounts, software libraries, workflow automation), change windows, and monitoring unauthorized access attempts
procedures.rationale: Control requires 'enforce...access restrictions' - procedure defines technical and physical enforcement mechanisms per NIST discussion examples

executionEvidence.name: Change Access Restrictions Documentation
executionEvidence.description: Document defining: roles authorized to make changes per system type, qualification requirements for each role, physical access restrictions (facility areas, locked rooms), logical access restrictions (privileged accounts, software libraries), change windows (times when changes allowed), enforcement mechanisms (access controls, workflow automation)
executionEvidence.rationale: Direct evidence of 'define...access restrictions' requirement. Demonstrates what restrictions are established. Annual review is best practice; 18-month threshold before staleness

executionEvidence.name: Change Access Authorization Records
executionEvidence.description: Records showing: individuals authorized for change access, systems/components they can modify, authorization date, approver signature, qualification verification completed, access level granted, expiration date if time-limited
executionEvidence.freshnessThreshold: N/A - maintained for audit, but periodic reviews required
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates 'approve...access restrictions' requirement - shows formal authorization process for granting change access

executionEvidence.name: Change Access Review Reports
executionEvidence.description: Quarterly access review reports showing: all individuals with change access reviewed, current qualifications verified, unnecessary access removed, role changes reflected, review date, reviewer signatures
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates ongoing enforcement and appropriateness of access restrictions. Quarterly reviews align with best practices. 120-day threshold allows one missed cycle

executionEvidence.name: Physical Access Control Evidence
executionEvidence.description: Evidence of physical restrictions including: facility access logs for areas where changes occur, key/badge access lists for server rooms/network closets, photo evidence of locked cabinets/cages, physical access violation reports
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion explicitly mentions 'physical...access controls' - evidence demonstrates physical restrictions are enforced per requirement

executionEvidence.name: Logical Access Control Evidence
executionEvidence.description: Evidence of logical restrictions including: privileged account listings for change-authorized personnel, software library access controls configured, workflow automation logs showing approval enforcement, change window configurations, unauthorized access attempt logs
executionEvidence.rationale: NIST discussion mentions 'logical access controls, software libraries, workflow automation...change windows' - demonstrates technical enforcement mechanisms

executionEvidence.name: Change Access Violation Reports
executionEvidence.description: Reports of unauthorized change attempts showing: unauthorized access detected, individual involved, system affected, violation date/time, investigation results, disciplinary action taken, corrective controls implemented
executionEvidence.rationale: Demonstrates access restrictions are actively enforced and violations are detected and addressed - evidence of 'enforce' requirement

physicalEvidence.name: Physical Access Control Documentation
physicalEvidence.description: Documentation of physical security measures for change access including: facility access control procedures, server room/network closet access requirements, locked cabinet/cage configurations, surveillance system coverage
physicalEvidence.rationale: Control explicitly requires 'physical...access restrictions' - demonstrates physical security measures are in place per NIST discussion

operationalActivities: Define qualification requirements for personnel authorized to make changes
Document physical and logical access restrictions for change activities
Grant change access only to qualified and authorized individuals
Implement physical access controls (locked rooms, badge access) for change areas
Configure logical access controls (privileged accounts, software libraries, workflow automation)
Enforce change windows restricting when changes can occur
Conduct quarterly reviews of all change access authorizations
Monitor and investigate unauthorized change access attempts
Remove change access when individuals no longer require it or are no longer qualified
Maintain audit logs of all change-related access events
